So what do we really do?
So our mandate is to really help Canadian businesses build their capacity and to do that we have a number of products.
The first, the first 2 products are what we refer to as financing products and subordinated financing is just another financing product with a higher risk.
Those two products are primarily aimed at existing small to medium enterprises.
These are enterprises that have revenues in our cash flow positive, so these are not VC type of businesses typically tend to be lifestyle businesses.
This is not the kind of investment that's going to create 100 X return, but.
We're basically playing a role in the marketplace by taking an edit layer of risk to help his entrepreneurs.
Very traditional bank will not provide that incremental working capital or loan because of the balance sheet risk.
So this is where we step in and take that extra layer of risk.

And as you can appreciate, most of VC investments fail, so then you hope that within your portfolio there are one or two or three that make up for all the bad decisions you've made right, but that's another story for another day.
We also have a consulting services group, so again the Consulting Group is aimed at helping, not the venture backed companies, but the existing small to medium enterprises who need help.

It is knowledge based industries that create productivity gains and productivity gains is warped, ultimately allows each of the economies to sustain its standard of living.
Again, nothing different here.
We focus on early stage investment startups, both direct and indirect.
We have a mandate to commercialize research at a University in government labs and we'll talk about that.
We have a mandate to focus on leading edge technologies and what that means is we're looking for disruptive stuff we're not interested in incremental improvements.
Because that doesn't really help us achieve achieve the desired objectives.
Attracting foreign investors is important, 'cause even within our fund we have limited resources or soft cap.
So in any given company we have a limit of how much we can put in and that amount is 10,000,000.
So for example, let's say you're looking at a an opportunity that requires $50,000,000 to get to an exit.
That means that we have to be able to attract an additional $40,000,000 from investors within Canada and outside of Canada, and that's important.
The one aspect that I think is is extremely, extremely important is what I refer to here is investment in companies with global potential.
What do we mean by that?
As a venture capitalist, even in a Development Bank, keep in mind that when you invest in a company, this is not a two year effort.
Yeah, you get lucky once in awhile and we had this great bubble in the 90s, but we're back to reality.
That means that it takes 8 to 10 years to really build a company that takes a lot of hard work.

Less of an interest to us.

Learning for all of us in the room.
The original technology for BTI Systems was in optical components and it came out of the National Research Labs National Research Council, Government Lab in Canada.

The company started out as an optical components company and then as you all know, in 2001, the optical telecom bubble exploded and this company very quickly realized that components was being commoditized.
An trying to stay on that path was actually an unsustainable strategy and eventually would result in the demise of the comp.
Hey.

More effectively, but in the venture capital world today, capital efficiency is very critical.
